snippet: The Yankees and the Mets play Tuesday and Wednesday in Florida to wrap up their spring training.
abstract: New York Yankees and New York Mets will play each other in Florida to wrap up their spring training.

headline.main: Yankees and Mets Resuming Rivalry Down South
headline.print_headline: Yankees and Mets Resuming Rivalry Down South

snippet: Path, the mobile social network, said that it had added a privacy feature to its mobile application after it was discovered that some app makers were copying address data without permission.
abstract: Path, the mobile social network, said that it had added a privacy feature to its mobile application after it was discovered that some app makers were copying address data without permission.

headline.main: Path Improves Security in Mobile App

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an artist whose canvas is snow and whose brushes are his feet, a discussion of how much money Google takes in vi...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an artist whose canvas is snow and whose brushes are his feet, a discussion of how much money Google takes in via Android and an experimental health sensor tattoo.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Twitter Women and Tablet Ratings

snippet: Nokia's strategy to sell its new Lumia smartphone is to make you feel dumb about what you already have. New video ads from Nokia, the Finnish phone maker, suggest that iPhones and Android phones are flawed, unfinished "beta" devices, which makes y...
abstract: Nokia's strategy to sell its new Lumia smartphone is to make you feel dumb about what you already have. New video ads from Nokia, the Finnish phone maker, suggest that iPhones and Android phones are flawed, unfinished "beta" devices, which makes you a sucker for having one.

headline.main: Nokia's Lumia Ads Say Your Phone Is No Good

snippet: A new show at the Grolier Club on the Upper East Side conjures memories of the glorious bookstores designed by Ernest Flagg for the firm of Charles Scribner's Sons. Fortunately, both turn-of-the-century spaces still exist.
abstract: A new show at the Grolier Club on the Upper East Side conjures memories of the glorious bookstores designed by Ernest Flagg for the firm of Charles Scribner's Sons. Fortunately, both turn-of-the-century spaces still exist.

headline.print_headline: When Displaying Books Evoked a Sense of Awe

snippet: The front of the iPad has one button, and that is one physical button too many. For the last couple of weeks I've been using the iPad without touching that home button, and it's often a more enjoyable way to use the device.
abstract: The front of the iPad has one button, and that is one physical button too many. For the last couple of weeks I've been using the iPad without touching that home button, and it's often a more enjoyable way to use the device.

headline.main: Does the iPad Have One Button Too Many?

snippet: Wall Street held on to its gains after a private survey showed the American manufacturing industry growing.
abstract: Stocks rise on stronger-than-forecast growth in manufacturing.

headline.main: Major Indexes Rise on Manufacturing Data
headline.print_headline: Major Indexes Rise On Manufacturing Data

snippet: Since Timothy D. Cook, Apple's chief executive, took over management of the company, Apple has made a number of significant moves to address concerns about how its products are made, reports Nick Wingfield in Monday's New York Times. And it may we...
abstract: Since Timothy D. Cook, Apple's chief executive, took over management of the company, Apple has made a number of significant moves to address concerns about how its products are made, reports Nick Wingfield in Monday's New York Times. And it may well be in this area that Mr. Cook makes his earliest and most important mark on the company.

headline.main: Daily Report: Fixing Apple's Supply Lines
